On the Approximation and Smoothed Complexity of
Leontief Market Equilibria

Li-Sha Huang

Abstract

We show that the problem of finding an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-approximate Nash equilibrium of an nÃ—nğ‘›ğ‘›n\times nitalic_n Ã— italic_n two-person games can be reduced to the computation of an (Ïµ/n)2superscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘›2(\epsilon/n)^{2}( italic_Ïµ / italic_n ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-approximate market equilibrium of a Leontief economy. Together with a recent result of Chen, Deng and Teng, this polynomial reduction implies that the Leontief market exchange problem does not have a fully polynomial-time approximation scheme, that is, there is no algorithm that can compute an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-approximate market equilibrium in time polynomial in mğ‘šmitalic_m, nğ‘›nitalic_n, and 1/Ïµ1italic-Ïµ1/\epsilon1 / italic_Ïµ, unless PPAD âŠ†\subseteqâŠ† P, We also extend the analysis of our reduction to show, unless PPAD âŠ†\subseteqâŠ† RP, that the smoothed complexity of the Scarfâ€™s general fixed-point approximation algorithm (when applying to solve the approximate Leontief market exchange problem) or of any algorithm for computing an approximate market equilibrium of Leontief economies is not polynomial in nğ‘›nitalic_n and 1/Ïƒ1ğœ1/\sigma1 / italic_Ïƒ, under Gaussian or uniform perturbations with magnitude Ïƒğœ\sigmaitalic_Ïƒ.

The individual objective of each trader is to maximize his or her utility. Then the whole exchange can be conceptually characterized as: the traders sell their endowments â€“ to obtain money or budgets â€“ and individually optimize their objectives by buying the bundles of goods that maximize their utilities.

In other words, an equilibrium price vector essentially allows each trader to make individual decision without considering othersâ€™ utilities nor how they achieve their objectives.

The computation of a market equilibrium is a fundamental problem in modern economics [23] as Walrasian equilibria might provide useful information for the prediction of market trends, in the decision for future investments, and in the development of economic policies. So a central complexity question in Leontief market exchange problem is:

Question 1 (Polynomial Leontief?).

Is the problem of computing an equilibrium of a Leontief economy in P?

So far no polynomial-time algorithm has been found for this problem. In practice, one may be willing to relax the condition of equilibria and considers the computation of approximate market equilibria. For example, Scarf [22] developed a general algorithm for computing approximate fixed points and equilibria. Recently, Deng, Papadimitriou, Safra [8] proposed a notion of an approximate market equilibrium as a price vector that allows each trader to independently and approximately optimize her utilities.

Question 2 (Fully Polynomial Approximate Leontief?).

Can an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-approximate equilibrium of a Leontief economy with mğ‘šmitalic_m goods and nğ‘›nitalic_n traders be computed in time polynomial in mğ‘šmitalic_m, nğ‘›nitalic_n, and 1/Ïµ1italic-Ïµ1/\epsilon1 / italic_Ïµ?

The combination of two recent results greatly dashed the hope for a positive answer to Question 1. Codenotti, Saberi, Varadarajan, and Ye [5] gave a polynomial-time reduction from two-person games to a special case of the Leontief economy. In a remarkable breakthrough, Chen and Deng [3] subsequently proved that the problem of finding a Nash equilibrium of a two-person game is PPAD-complete333We refer the readers who are not familiar with the complexity class PPAD to the paper by Papadimitriou [21] and also to the subsequent papers on the PPAD-completeness of normal games [6, 2, 7, 3, 4]. This class includes several important search problems such as various discrete fixed-point problems and the problem of finding a Nash equilibrium of rğ‘Ÿritalic_r-person games for any fixed rğ‘Ÿritalic_r. .

In this paper, we show that there is no fully polynomial-time approximation scheme for Leontief economies unless PPAD âŠ†\subseteqâŠ† P. Hence it is unlikely that Question 2 has a positive answer. By analyzing the numerical properties of the reduction of Condenotti, Saberi, Varadarajan, and Ye [5], we prove that the problem of finding an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-approximate Nash equilibrium of an nÃ—nğ‘›ğ‘›n\times nitalic_n Ã— italic_n two-person games can be reduced to the computation of an (Ïµ/n)2superscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘›2(\epsilon/n)^{2}( italic_Ïµ / italic_n ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-approximate equilibrium of a Leontief economy with 2â¢n2ğ‘›2n2 italic_n goods and 2â¢n2ğ‘›2n2 italic_n traders. This polynomial relationship between approximate Nash equilibria of bimatrix games and approximate Walrasian equilibria of Leontief economies is significant because it enables us to apply the recent result of Chen, Deng, and Teng [4] to show that finding an approximate market equilibrium with only Oâ¢(logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log n)italic_O ( roman_log italic_n )-bits of precision is as hard as finding an exact market equilibrium, which in turn is as hard as finding a Nash equilibrium of a two-person game or a discrete Brouwer fixed point in the most general settings.

We also consider the smoothed complexity of the Leontief market exchange problem. In the smoothed model introduced by Spielman and Teng [24], an algorithm receives and solves a perturbed instances. The smoothed complexity of an algorithm is the maximum over its inputs of the expected running time of the algorithm under slight random perturbations of that input. The smoothed complexity is then measured as a function of both the input length and the magnitude Ïƒğœ\sigmaitalic_Ïƒ of the perturbations. An algorithm has smoothed polynomial-time complexity if its smoothed measure is polynomial in nğ‘›nitalic_n, the problem size, and in 1/Ïƒ1ğœ1/\sigma1 / italic_Ïƒ [24, 25].

The following has been an open question in the smoothed analysis of algorithms.

Question 3 (Smoothed Polynomial Leontief?).

Can an equilibrium of a Leontief economy be computed in smoothed time polynomial in mğ‘šmitalic_m, nğ‘›nitalic_n, and 1/Ïƒ1ğœ1/\sigma1 / italic_Ïƒ?

Can an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-equilibrium of a Leontief economy be computed in smoothed time polynomial in mğ‘šmitalic_m, nğ‘›nitalic_n, 1/Ïµ1italic-Ïµ1/\epsilon1 / italic_Ïµ and 1/Ïƒ1ğœ1/\sigma1 / italic_Ïƒ?

A concrete open question has been whether the smoothed complexity of the classic Scarfâ€™s general fixed-point approximation algorithm [22] is polynomial for solving the Leontief market exchange problem.

By refining our analysis of the reduction from the two-person games to Leontief economies, we show it is unlikely that Scarfâ€™s algorithm has polynomial smoothed complexity for computing an approximate equilibrium of Leontief economies. In particular, we prove that, unless PPAD âŠ†\subseteqâŠ† RP, the problem of finding an (approximate) equilibrium of a Leontief economy is not in smoothed polynomial time.

3 Approximate Nash Equilibria of Two-Person Games

The non-zero-sum two-person game or the bimatrix game is a non-cooperative game between two players [18, 15, 16], the row player and the column player. Every two-person game has at least one Nash equilibrium [18]. But in a recent breakthrough, Chen and Deng [3] proved that the problem of computing a Nash equilibrium of a two-person game is PPAD-complete.

One can relax the condition of Nash equilibria and considers approximate Nash equilibria. There are two possible notions of approximation.

Corollary 3.4 (Relative approximation is also hard).

To relate the complexity of finding an approximate Nash equilibrium of two-person games with the smoothed complexity of Leontief economies, we examine the equilibria of perturbations of the reduction presented in the last subsection. 6 Remarks and Open Questions

In this section, we briefly summarize some remarkable algorithmic accomplishments in the computation of (approximate) market equilibria obtained prior to this work. We then present some open questions motivated by these and our new results.

6.1 General Market Exchange Problems and Algorithmic Results

In our paper, we have focused on Leontief market exchange economies. Various other market economies have been considered in the literature [23, 9].

An instance of a general market exchange economy with nğ‘›nitalic_n traders and mğ‘šmitalic_m goods is given by the endowment matrix ğ„ğ„\mathbf{E}bold_E together with nğ‘›nitalic_n utilities functions v1,â€¦,vnsubscriptğ‘£1â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›v_{1},\dots,v_{n}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then an equilibrium price vector is a vector ğ©ğ©\mathbf{p}bold_p satisfying

The celebrated theorem of Arrow and Debreu [1] states that if all utility functions are concave, then the exchange economy has an equilibrium. Moreover, if these functions are strictly concave, then for each equilibrium price vector ğ©ğ©\mathbf{p}bold_p, its associated exchange ğ—ğ—\mathbf{X}bold_X or utilities is unique.

A popular family of utility functions is the CES (standing for Constant Elasticity of Substitution) utility functions. It is specified by an mÃ—nğ‘šğ‘›m\times nitalic_m Ã— italic_n demand matrix ğƒğƒ\mathbf{D}bold_D. The utility functions are then defined with the help of an additional parameter Ïâˆˆ(âˆ’âˆ,1]âˆ–{0}ğœŒ10\rho\in(-\infty,1]\setminus\left\{{0}\right\}italic_Ï âˆˆ ( - âˆ , 1 ] âˆ– { 0 }:

As Ïâ†’âˆ’âˆâ†’ğœŒ\rho\rightarrow-\inftyitalic_Ï â†’ - âˆ, CES utilities become the Leontief utilities. When Ï=1ğœŒ1\rho=1italic_Ï = 1, the utility functions are linear functions.

Remarkablely, an (approximate) equilibrium of an exchange economy with linear utilities functions can be found in polynomial time [20, 12, 27, 13]. In fact, Ye shows that an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-equilibrium of such an market with nğ‘›nitalic_n traders and nğ‘›nitalic_n goods can be found in Oâ¢(n4â¢logâ¡(1/Ïµ))ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›41italic-ÏµO(n^{4}\log(1/\epsilon))italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log ( 1 / italic_Ïµ ) ) time [27]. If data is given as rational numbers of Lğ¿Litalic_L-bits, then an exact equilibrium can be found in Oâ¢(n4â¢L)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›4ğ¿O(n^{4}L)italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L ) time.

A closely related market exchange model is the Fisherâ€™s model [23]. In this model, there are two types of traders: producers and consumers. Each consumer comes to the market with a budget and a utility function. Each producer comes to the market with an endowment of goods and will sell them to the consumers for money. An equilibrium is a price vector ğ©ğ©\mathbf{p}bold_p for goods so that if each consumer spends all her budget to maximize her utilities, then the market clears, i.e., at the end of the exchange, all producers sold out.

Even more remarkablely, an (approximate) equilibrium in a Fisherâ€™s economy with any CES utilities can be found in polynomial time [11, 27, 28, 10, 14].

6.2 Open Questions

Our results as well as the combination of Codenotti, Saberi, Varadarajan, and Ye [5] and Chen and Deng [3] demonstrate that exchange economies with Leontief utility functions are fundamentally different from economies with linear utility functions. In Leontief economies, not only finding an exact equilibrium is likely hard, but finding an approximate equilibrium is just as hard.

Although, we prove that the computation of an Oâ¢(1/nÎ˜â¢(1))ğ‘‚1superscriptğ‘›Î˜1O(1/n^{\Theta(1)})italic_O ( 1 / italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î˜ ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )-approximate equilibrium of Leontief economies is PPAD-hard. our hardness result does not cover the case when Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ is a constant between 00 and 1111. The following are two optimistic conjectures.

Conjecture 4 (PTAS Approximate LEONTIEF).

There is an algorithm to find an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-approximate equilibrium of a Leontief economy in time Oâ¢(nk+Ïµâˆ’c)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜superscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘O(n^{k+\epsilon^{-c}})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_c end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) for some positive constants cğ‘citalic_c and kğ‘˜kitalic_k.

Conjecture 5 (Smoothed LEONTIEF: Constant Perturbations).

There is an algorithm to find an equilibrium of a Leontief economy with smoothed time complexity Oâ¢(nk+Ïƒâˆ’c)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜superscriptğœğ‘O(n^{k+\sigma^{-c}})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_c end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) under perturbations with magnitude Ïƒğœ\sigmaitalic_Ïƒ, for some positive constants cğ‘citalic_c and kğ‘˜kitalic_k.
